abstracts.cdata!:
The Decentralization and Community
            Development Project for Rwanda contributes to Rwanda's
            long-term goal for decentralization and a realigned mandate
            for central government, through the empowerment and improved
            accountability of local governments and communities.   (CDD)
            The short-term project objective is to scale out validated
            project experience in the country, particularly by extending
            the community-driven development (CDD) strategy of the
            precursor Community Reintegration and Development Project (a
            LIL), from 11 to 39 Districts. The specific development
            objectives are to: (1) strengthen District capacity to lead
            a process of planning and consultation with local
            communities, translating their development priorities into
            sub-projects which are incorporated into Districts'
            strategic development plans; (2) develop a matching grants
            system to finance the sub-projects; (3) validate procedures
            for decentralized project cycle management and financial
            management; and (4) introduce and promote public awareness
            programs.   The project includes four components: (1)
            Institutional Capacity Building: The Project will support
            the Government's decentralization policy by
            strengthening institutions' and communities'
            capacity  to plan, implement, manage, finance, and maintain
            development activities. Activities to be financed by the
            project include a broad spectrum of training workshops and
            on-the-job training at all levels of implementation;  (2)
            Information, Education and Communications: The component
            will inform and educate different players at all levels
            regarding the objectives, activities and modalities of
            decentralization and the relevant laws and regulations, so
            that populations are aware of their rights and are included
            in the processes. The communications strategy will also
            support the project's participatory monitoring and
            evaluation, including "social audits" for feedback
            from the communities on project process and results.  , (3)
            Community Development Initiatives: This component will
            finance grants to participating communities in the 39
            supported Districts for community-based sub-projects. (4)
            Program management, monitoring and evaluation: The project
            will adopt a decentralized approach to coordination and
            management.   The project design takes into account that
            Rwanda's post-conflict environment is dynamic, yet
            somewhat unbalanced.
